reviewText: This season of SMDM brought us even more exciting adventures. It opens with the 2 part story, "The Return of the Bionic Woman" and also includes the popular "Secret of Bigfoot" 2 part episodes. Probably the most watched episodes of the entire 3rd season. This set, identical to that released a few years ago by TimeLife, also features the Spinoff episodes of "The Bionic Woman" series. There seems to be some disagreement by the archival records as to whether or not the first episode was a SMDM episode and the 2nd part was the 1st episode of the BW series but as shown on this set, they appear to both be from the BW series, although SCI-FI Channel had broadcast Part 1 with closing credits from the SMDM version....(I have the tape to prove that somewhere)nevertheless, its great to see older shows being able to get their due on DVD.  Could you imagine if we were still stuck with VHS tapes, each complete season would consist of 12 tapes and that's a lot of shelf space. If it weren't for DVD, over half the shows we watched probably would never appear for purchase...ever. The overall video and audio quality is broadcast quality, a bit grainy, but keep in mind this series was shot on film, not videotape. It looks great, even when stretched to fit on a wide HD equipped TVs.
summary: Finally, the casssic series on DVD.

reviewText: I could not wait for the Six Million Dollar Man to come out on DVD.  Like most 40-50 year olds, this was my favorite series when growing up in the 70's.  Sure the special effects are not all CGI and glossy like they are today, but they're not bad for the time and heaven knows even the worst stript and plot for TSMDM is ten times better than half of the sci-fi trash that is put out there now days.  Lee Majors was made for the role and may be more assoicated with it than just about any actor could be with a role.  I agree with most that season Two was probably better overall, but this is the first season we all got to see Steve Austin take on that other 70's icon "Bigfoot".  That alone makes this five stars.  Harve Bennett was on top of his game when producing this series and Richard Anderson as Oscar Goldman may be as famous for that role as Majors was with Austin.  I will not bore you with episode lists and views on each one, but I will say if you love sci-fi and if you grew up in the 70's, this is a must buy not only for its excellent entertainment, but the trip down memory lane when TV was worth a darn.
summary: When TV Was Original and Worth Watching

reviewText: I loved this show when I was a kid, and as an adult it does not disappoint.  Sure, there are some corny moments and of course there is none of the graphic violence and blood and guts we see on current programs - a plus in my book.  What we do have are characters who represent the best that America has to offer; Colonel Austin is a true American hero, very modest and unselfish, and I think a pre-cursor to modern characters like Leroy Jethro Gibbs in NCIS.  And, for those who enjoy classic cars, and retro fashions, this show has plenty of both.  Can't wait for Season 4 to be available on Amazon!!

reviewText: They had the technology, they could rebuild him.  Probably Lee Majors best role ever was as Colonel Steve Austin on The Six Million Dollar Man.  I love the series.  But the writers were not consistent, ended up killing the show over the Austin/Sommers romance I believe.  Some of the stories got to be too fantastic and hard to bel...  What am I saying, the entire thing is impossible to believe but it was a grear escape for me as a child.  When Jamie Sommers came along, GASP, well I was just in heaven to have some feminine girl who could kick all the big boys asps.  WONDERFUL.  Basically Austin was an astronaut/tester for NASA and such who was in a near fatal crash of an experimental  craft.  They could rebuild him, they had the technology to build the world's first bionic man.  This is English Subtitled for the deaf and hearing impaired.  Bless 'em for that.

reviewText: Lee Majors as Steve Austin is such a stud!!!  While I enjoy him in his other Big Valley and Fall Guy series, this is the perfect role for him, the right actor playing the right character at just the right time.  He's the prototype for what a man can be, strong yet sensitive and caring about others.  He shows me how to be a better man.  He only uses his bionic powers when needed.The 2-part "Secret of Bigfoot" is a fairly satisfying explanation of the Bigfoot legend (I won't spoil the secret) and there are so many other great episodes.  I loved the return of the Seven Million Dollar Man in "Bionic Criminal", and I particularly enjoyed the very last episode of the season, "Big Brother", where Steve Austin plays big brother to a poor Latin kid embroiled in an inner-city gambling debt, to be settled by some bionic basketball.  Exhilarating!

reviewText: The only reason I'm giving season three a 4-star review rather than a 5-star one is because there is a bit too much "Bionic Woman" included in this season. The Six Million Dollar Man was and still is one of my all-time favorite shows. The introduction of The Bionic Woman (which of course actually began at the end of season two) did not capture my interest, then or now. It's nothing against Lindsay Wagner, let alone Jamie Summers ... but Steve Austin was unique and I guess I wanted him to remain that way. In fairness to Jamie / Lindsay, I felt this way every time another "bionic" character was introduced (mostly in the movies that aired years after the series ended).All that said, season 3 does have some wonderful episodes and is a must-have for fans of the series. In addition to seeing Steve going undercover as a lumberjack, a longshoreman and even a police officer, he meets up with Big Foot for the first time. The 2-part Big Foot episode is reason enough for Six Million Dollar Man fans to get a hold of season 3. I can still remember seeing the Big Foot episode when I was very young and also remember Universal Studios having a Bionic Show and other SMDM related attractions at the time. In fact, the rotating tunnel is still a part of their tram tour and it always reminds me of Steve Austin and Big Foot. Seasons 1 and 2 are better overall, in my opinion, but that doesn't mean that season 3 should be missed. I recommend it to all Six Million Dollar Man fans ~~ young and old ~~~ as well as newcomers to the show.
summary: It's the one with Big Foot .......

reviewText: The Bigfoot episodes make this worth the price of the set.  I haven't seen these since 1976!  The SMDM was one of the best TV shows of it's time.  The directors commentary by Kenny Johnson was very insightful on the production and the problems of creating a TV show in the 1970's.  If only there were more director's commentary on these sets!  I loved this show as a kid and still will watch it again and again.  It brought back a lot of memories!  There is even a commetary on an episode by director Cliff Bole.  Cliff also directed many great episodes of Star Trek: The Next Generation.  As a sci fi TV fan, this is not a set you want to miss.
summary: The Season of Bigfoot vs. The Six Million Dollar Man!
Title: N/A

reviewText: "Season Three" of the Six Million Dollar Man does not offer quite as many high quality episodes as Season Two, which to me, was the high water mark of the series, but it comes pretty close as the show was maturing on many levels."The Return of the Bionic Woman" kicks off Season Three in grand style as a two-part episode and is just as good as the original episodes that introduced this great character (Jaime S.) a season earlier.  This season also contains the two part "Secret of Bigfoot" episodes with "Andre The Giant" in the title role.  As has been noted in other reviews, Bigfoot sightings were a big deal at that time so quite topical and I was simply spellbound when it originally aired.  Stefanie Powers also was absolutely gorgeous as an alien in this one.  Several other episodic attempts were made at "Bigfoot" in subsequent seasons but none held the charm of this first outing.In between these two bookends, there are some other episodes in Season Three worthy of mention.  "The Seven Million Dollar Man" returns for a second engagement in "The Bionic Criminal".  Although not quite as good as the first episode from Season Two, it is still pretty solid.  There are also several amusing episodes such as "The Song and Dance Spy" guest starring Sonny Bono and two episodes where our Hero Col. Steve Austin tangles with more local type criminals in "The White Lightning War" and "Target in the Sky" which are all enjoyable entries.  For football enthusiasts, another change of pace is offered in "One of Our Running Backs is Missing" which featured Larry Cszonka and Dick Butkus as well as Carl Weathers of "Rocky-Apollo Creed" Fame in an early role.  "The Winning Smile" is another episode featuring Oscar Goldman's Secretary, Peggy Callahan, who became a semi-regular shortly thereafter on both the "Six Million Dollar Man" and "Bionic Woman" Series.Overall, I can't give this season Five Stars like Season Two but all in all, a very good season with several excellent episodes so not to be overlooked!
summary: Bionic Woman & Bigfoot are the Highlights!

reviewText: This 1975-76 Season was awesome along with the fact that THE SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN ran on ABC for 4 years and was based on a novel Cyborg by Marty Caiden and referred to a former astronaut Col. Steve Austin(Lee Majors)who nearly died after being seriously injured on a mission and gets rescued by Agent Oscar Goldman(Richard Anderson)from the Office of Scientific Intelligence and gets rebuilt by Dr. Rudy Wells(Martin E. Brooks)with surgical bionic implants very similar to his love-interest Jamie Sommars(Lindsay Wagner)on its spin-off series THE BIONIC WOMAN which premiered on ABC in the Winter of 1976.As a result Steve's bionic capabilities, Steve had an infrared left-eye kind of like Jamie had an amplifying right-ear, plus Steve and Jamie would often team up together on cases in crossover episodes of both THE SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN and THE BIONIC WOMAN.Lee Majors had opened the minds and hearts of audiences all across the world to an era when we were starving for super-heros especially when we had a knack for being able to help mediate problems to a point where the only resolution was by the hand since THE SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN introduced a new concept to our world of robots and cyborgs in order to enhance his ability to combat everything that was evil since Steve inspired us with hope along with the fact that the debut of THE BIONIC WOMAN was inspired by THE SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN as well.Unfortunately THE SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN was cancelled in the Spring of 1978 around the same time THE BIONIC WOMAN was, due to slumping ratings when creator(Ken Johnson)had THE INCREDIBLE HULK make its debut on CBS in March of 1978 which was an even bigger smash and even bigger success than THE BIONIC WOMAN and THE SIX MILLION DOLLAR MAN.It was also interesting seeing guest starring apperances by*Sonny Bono in "The Song & Dance Spy" episode during his co-starring days on THE SONY & CHER SHOW*Quinn Redeker in "The Wolf Boy" episode before his co-starring days as inclusive Rex Sterling on THE YOUNG & THE RESTLESS*Football celebrity Dick Butkus in the "One of Our Running Backs is Missing" episode*Tim O'Connor in "The Deadly Test" episode before his co-starring days as Dr. Huer on BUCK ROGERS*Carl Weathers in the "One of Our Running Backs is Missing" episode before his co-starring days as Apollo in the ROCKY movies*Monte Markham in "The Bionic Criminal" episode before his co-starring days as Capt. Don Thorpe on BAYWATCH*Michael Conrad in "The Blue Flash" episode before his co-starring days as Sgt. Phil on the police drama HILL STREET BLUES*Jack Colvin in the "Hocus-Pocus" episode before his co-starring days as the obsessed overzealous reporter(Jack McGee)on THE INCREDIBLE HULK*Deceased wrestler Andre the Giant in "The Secret of Bigfoot" episode*Louis Gossett, Jr. in the "Clark Tempelton O'Flaherty" episode*Stefanie Powers in "The Secret of Bigfoot" episode before her co-starring days on the detective drama HART TO HART*Charles Cyphers known for his role as the concerned, but skeptical Sheriff Brackett in the movie HALLOWEEN*Farrah Fawcett in "The Golden Pharaoh" episode during her co-starring days on CHARLIE'S ANGELS*Noah Beery in "The Bionic Badge" episode during his co-starring days as Joseph "Rocky" Rockford on THE ROCKFORD FILES
summary: Takes me back to memory lane!
